prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
WIBTA if I make my gf start paying some of the bills over a single incident?
Gf and I live together.   She only works part time.    I pay all the rent and bill.  I never minded it until last night. 

We went to grab some take out and I realized I left my wallet in my work pants.  I told her she’d have to get it.   Her attitude about the whole thing was so ugly.   At first she couldn’t believe it and asked me if I was serious in this almost disgusted tone.  She acted so put out by it. 

It was some fucking take out.  Under $40.  I pay EVERYTHING.  I understand she only makes a little, but that little is probably a lot with no expenses.   I know it was only one incident, but I haven’t been able to get it out of my head since.   It’s really rubbing my the wrong way.  She wouldn’t be able to pay a lot of the bills, but I feel like it’s time for her to start carrying her weight.  Just out of principal.  
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's try to figure out if the author is in the wrong here. The situation is about a couple where the author is the main financial provider, paying all the bills and rent. The girlfriend only works part-time. The issue arose when the author forgot his wallet and asked her to pay for the takeout, which was under $40. She had a bad attitude about it, and now the author is considering making her start contributing to the bills.

First, I need to consider the dynamics of their relationship. The author has been paying everything, which might have set a precedent. The girlfriend's reaction might have been frustrating because she's not used to contributing, but does that make the author in the wrong? 

The author is now thinking about making her start paying some bills over a single incident. That seems a bit harsh, especially since the takeout was a minor expense. The author mentions it's principal, but maybe it's more about the reaction than the amount. However, the author also points out that the girlfriend can't cover the majority of the bills, so expecting her to contribute more might be reasonable in the long run but using a $40 incident as the trigger could be disproportionate.

Another angle is communication. The author might not have discussed expectations about shared expenses before, leading to this misunderstanding. The girlfriend's attitude might stem from feeling that this is an unfair sudden demand, especially if she's not working full-time. The author's frustration is understandable, but using a single incident to demand a significant change in financial responsibility could be seen as holding a grudge or overreacting.

On the other hand, the author might feel entitled to expect mutual responsibility. If the author has always paid everything, maybe the girlfriend doesn't realize the expectation to contribute. But expecting her to take on a significant portion of the bills after a small incident might not be fair either. The author should probably have a conversation about splitting costs more equitably rather than punishing her over one event.

So, is the author in the wrong? The key points are the proportionality of the response and the lack of prior communication. The author is using a minor incident to enforce a major change, which could be disproportionate. Also, if they haven't discussed financial responsibilities before, this might be the author's fault for not setting clear expectations. Therefore, the answer might lean towards A (the author is in the wrong) because the response is overly harsh for the situation and lacks prior discussion.
